items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
Property flooding is possible. A Flood Warning is in force on the River levels have risen on the Mill Brook from the Hagbourne Mill area to Winterbrook. River levels on the Mill Brook, a tributary of the River Thames, are high as a result of heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads and property is expected to continue overnight 23/09/2024, especially in the areas closest to the Mill Brook in the Blewbury area. Levels on the River Thames remain below the flood risk threshold. 

Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight, clearing by the morning. River levels on the Mill Brook remain sensitive to rainfall and are expected to rise again in response to ongoing rainfall.   

Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. We are operating our weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels on the Bear and Wendover Brooks are high but have stabilised following heavy rainfall throughout today. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected to continue overnight 23/09/2024 and into tomorrow, especially in the areas closest to the Bear Brook in the urban reaches through Aylesbury. 

Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight clearing the area by the morning. River levels are currently gradually falling but are sensitive to further rainfall. We expect levels to rise again in response to rainfall overnight.    

Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. On Sunday night more than half a month's rain has been recorded at Cowbeech (35mm). From 10:30 23/09/2024 flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens including on Station Road, Church Lane, and Church Road, Hellingly. From 17:00 23/09/2024 minor flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 19:00 23/09/2024 in Hellingly, and in Alfriston by 02:00 24/09/2024, and should return to normal by Tuesday afternoon (24/09/2024). The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the next few weeks. More rain is forecast on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and flood risk could return. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 24/09/2024.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Mole.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight. Light rainfall is forecast tomorrow, 24/09/2024.

The River Ouse is higher than normal, but now slowly falling, following Sunday's rain. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields and roads through Monday night, affecting locations including Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, Barcombe Mills road, and fields and gardens near Barcombe Mills. Only isolated showers are forecast for Monday night and Tuesday 24/09/2024. The river should continue to fall, returning to normal by Tuesday afternoon. The river will be sensitive to rainfall over the next few weeks, and bands of rain are forecast between Wednesday and Friday 27/09/2024. Minor flood risk could return through the second half of this week. Some roads may be affected by flooding, including Barcombe Mills road, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 10:00 24/09/2024.

The River Adur is high and rising. On Sunday night 20mm of rain was recorded at Cowfold. From 15:00 23/09/2024 minor flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as some water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge. Only isolated showers are forecast over Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 17:00 23/09/2024, and should return to normal from 09:00 24/09/2024. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the next few weeks. More rain is forecast on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and flood risk could return. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 24/09/2024.

items.message: Heavy rain has fallen in the Nene catchment and will continue throughout the evening of Monday, September 23. This has caused Grendon Brook to rise and is forecast to continue to rise overnight. Low lying areas near to the Brook are already flooded and we expect properties in Grendon Brook catchment community to be affected from this evening onwards. Low lying properties near the river on Blackmile Lane in Grendon and Grendon Road, 600 Station Road, Mill Lane, Hardwater Road and Doddington Crossing are expected to be affected first. The Reservoirs around Grendon are full so will not be able to store any water so we expect the levels to be high for the next few days. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. Stay away from floodwater - it may contain hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels continue to rise as a result of recent rainfall.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, although property flooding is not expected.
Flooding of land is expected alongside the Medway during the evening of 23/09/24 and overnight into 24/09/24.
Areas most at risk include Tonbridge playing fields and town centre car parks and low lying land and roads from Tonbridge through Tudeley and East Peckham. This is likely to include the sports pitches, also known as the racecourse, in Tonbridge and around Tonbridge Sports Ground and Postern Lane.
Weather conditions are expected to be generally dry until further heavy rain expected on Wednesday
We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning for the Winford Brook has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout today on 24 September 2024 with some further rainfall forecast later on Wednesday.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels are rising on the River Sheppey due to heavy rainfall today. This Flood Warning has been issued because flooding is expected from around 5PM today, 23/09/2024. Areas most at risk include the area around Charlton Viaduct, the Cider Factory and Draycott Road in Shepton Mallet, and the area around Jack’s Bridge in Croscombe. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. 
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one, and consider activating any property flood protection products you may have. We are continually monitoring rainfall and river levels, and staff have been out checking rivers and weed screens in the area for blockages. Further rainfall is forecast tonight, before dry conditions are forecast tomorrow. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM tomorrow, 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels are high on the Bristol Frome this afternoon due to heavy rainfall. In the last 24 hours approximately 30mm of rain has fallen across the catchment. River levels on the Bristol Frome are rising and will remain high today, Monday 23 September 2024. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Areas most at risk include Yate and St John's Way in Chipping Sodbury and Damson Bridge.
We are not expecting flood warnings today. The weather outlook shows further rain forecast for the rest of this week that may result in flood warnings. We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Consider putting your flood plan into action. This message will be updated on the 24 September 2024 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Areas most at risk are properties close to the confluence in Adderbury, including those on Dog Close. The risk to properties close to the Bloxham Brook has reduced.
